Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: Collaborative Research: Integrated Biomimetic Block Copolymer Composite Membranes

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1512089/1512099
Phillip/Kumar
Notre Dame/Penn State

Mimicking biological membranes, which have developed innovative transport mechanisms through millennia of evolution, has gained increasing interest in recent years. In particular, biological membranes have embedded proteins that are capable of transporting chemical species into and out of cells efficiently and with exceptional selectivity. As such, developing membrane platforms that mimic the exquisite processes of biology provides a route toward performing many chemical separations that are critical to modern society (e.g., purification of drinking water). In order for these advanced membranes to make an impact on the chemical and biological separations the development of robust, high performance, composite membranes is required. These composite membranes comprise a biomimetic active layer containing membrane proteins supported mechanically by a highly-porous and permeable support layer. The generation of robust composite membranes, which realize the full potential of membrane proteins, requires that the active and support layers are integrated synergistically.

The goal of the proposed research project is to identify the key materials relationships that control the interplay between the nanostructures and chemistries of the copolymer supports and the biomimetic active layers in order to optimize the separations performance of composite biomimetic-block copolymer membranes (BBCMs). This novel class of membranes comprises a selective layer made from 2D crystals of membrane proteins and a support layer made from self-assembled copolymers.

The successful execution of this research project will deliver a transformative technology platform through an enhanced understanding of how to combine two self-assembled materials into a composite membrane relevant to a diversity of separations. Beyond the technical impact, a new generation of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students will be trained in a multi-disciplinary and collaborative setting. A summer camp for middle school students focused on water treatment will provide opportunities to bring this important application of membranes to a wider audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research Project Overview 

The long-term goal of this research project was to develop the fundamental knowledge that guides the design of biological inspired composite membranes for possible applications in a wide variety of fields including water treatment, food and beverage processing, and pharmaceutical purification. Specifically, the project sought to identify how the interactions between an active layer that mimics the architecture of the cell membrane could be integrated with highly porous support layers in a synergistic manner to promote the rapid and highly-selective separation of target molecules from multicomponent mixtures. As an important first step towards achieving this goal, an interdisciplinary collaboration between engineers within the Department of Chemical Engineering at Pennsylvania State University and the Department of Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering at the University of Notre Dame was initiated. This collaborative team worked to establish how the structural and chemical design of the active layer and support layer as well as the methods of integrating the two components affected the transport of solvent and solutes through the composite membranes. Because these transport rates govern the separation performance of the membranes, this knowledge begins to establish design rules for tailoring the membrane characteristics for directed applications.

 

Important Outcomes – Intellectual Merit

Membranes that incorporate biologically-inspired channels (e.g., membrane proteins and synthetic channels) have emerged as a promising platform for the execution of precise molecular separations. The knowledge developed through the execution of this project helped to advance this separations platform in several regards by demonstrating that large areas, ~50 cm2, of high-performance, biomimetic membranes can be made through the careful optimization of the packing of proteins in the top active layer and molecular design of the support layer. This demonstration relied on physical insights and advances regarding the active layer and support layer architectures as well as their integration. The design of two-dimensional crystals that incorporated channels at higher densities than in the vesicles previously used for the formation of channel-containing membranes was critical to realizing high-performance active layers. Additionally, it was shown that channel pore sizes could be rationally manipulated by utilizing an optimization-based protein redesign algorithm. The structure and chemistry of the support block copolymer membrane was optimized to provide both stability and a low resistance to flow of the water filtered through the active layer. Finally, a modified layer-by-layer technique allowed for the high-fidelity incorporation of two-dimensional crystals over large areas of the support membranes. This integration permitted the crystal structures within the active layer to govern transport through the composite membranes. Taken together this combination of advances helped to inform the development of membranes for precise chemical separations.

Important Outcomes – Broader Impact

The development of biologically inspired membranes is a novel approach to addressing the challenge of freshwater availability around the world by providing enabling technologies for upgrading marginal water sources, and reducing the cost of chemical and biopharmaceutical separations. The fundamental knowledge generated in this work takes important steps toward realizing the potential of this platform by helping to guide the fabrication of these membranes. In particular, by determining how to integrate high performance biologically inspired active layers with mechanical supports, a framework for how to generate these membranes, which promote the removal of target molecules, in a scalable manner has been made. In addition to the technical knowledge that was developed through the execution of this research project, support for this work led to the education and training of four graduate students and a postdoctoral fellow at the two collaborating universities. The students gained important skills in membrane science, polymer chemistry, and transport phenomena through hands-on laboratory experiences. Moreover, the collaborative nature of the work allowed students from Pennsylvania State University and the University of Notre Dame to perform work at the partner institution in order to gain a more diverse educational experience. In addition to graduate students, undergraduate and high school students contributed to research performed on this project. Outreach efforts included 1) the development of a traveling trunk, which can be utilized both on campus or taken to local elementary and high schools, focused on energy efficient separations, 2) participation in a science outreach booth at the Science Alive! event that is held each spring, and 3) aiding the execution of the Northern Indiana Regional Science and Engineering Fair. As such, this work contributed to the development of the next generation of diverse, interdisciplinary scientists and engineers.
